filings.text_data: OOCI\ET FILE COPY ORIGINAL EX PARTE OR LATE FILED ~-----------------------------------From: Sent: To: Subject: jimmy abbett <jimmyabbett@yahoo.com> Monday, December 09, 2013 5:01 PM Tom Wheeler Interstate Inmate Calling Services (WCDocket No. 12-375) ACCEPTED/FILED MAR 25 2014 Federal Communications Commission Office of the Secretary I am respectfully requesting your consideration for the ICS order (WC Docket No. 12-375) be stayed until the FCC and Sheriffs can determine a proper method for jails to recover cost. We do incur real cost to administer inmate calling service, however, the rates set by the FCC eliminate commissions to jails and on inter-state calls and does not include any allowance for cost recovery for jails. This would impact our current budget since the budget has already set for 2014. Your consideration in this matter will be appreciated. Thanks Sheriff Jimmy Abbett Tallapoosa County Sheriffs Department 316 Industrial Park Drive Dadeville, Alabama Office: 256-825-4264 Fax:256-825-1012 Email: jimmyabbett@yahoo.com ' 1

filings.text_data: This is to add to my previous comment about the costs of making a 15 minute phone call.  This call was from St George UT to Great Falls MT.  A total of 860 miles.   The same call in Great Falls to Great Falls.. Approximately $ 4.50 for the entire 15 minutes, which is still a complete ripoff.  If this is not pure greed and dishonesty then I don?t know what is.  The CEO and President needs to speed some time behind bars and see how it feels.  I would love for securus to break down exactly what their expense on this call was and what was their income.  I would bet it was about $ 1.00 in expenses.. and 8 dollars for the Cascade County Sherriff?s office and 12 dollars in profit for securus.  Again FCC please quickly rule on 12-375 as well as DENY 09-044 as illegal call blocking.

filings.text_data: In the Matter of Before the FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION Washington, D.C. 20554 WC Docket No. 12-375 Rates for Interstate Inmate Calling Services Reply Comments of the Montana Public Service Commission The Montana Public Service Commission (MPSC) respectfu lly submits these reply comments in response to comments filed in the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) 's September 26, 2013, Report and Order and Further Notice of Proposed Rulemaking in the matter of Rates for Interstate Inmate Calling Services. The MPSC strongly agrees with the comments filed by National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners (NARUC), indicating that, states are in the best position to oversee and investigate matters re lating to ICS INTRAstate rates and service quality,l and FCC action to expand its authority to affect INTRAstate rates can interfere with existing state programs and undermine State jurisdiction to handle related complaints and revise programs.2 The MPSC also agrees with Centurylink's comments, The Commission should respect the limits of its authority, decline to adopt additional intrastate ICS regulations, and instead leave regulation of intrastate ICS rates and related policy judgments to correctional institutions and the states.3 ' Rates for Interstate Inmate Calling Services, WC Docket No. 12-375, Comments of the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners, p.3, filed December 20, 2013. 21d. at 4. 3 Rates for Interstate Inmate Calling Services, WC Docket No. 12-375, Comments of Centurylink, p.2, filed December 20, 2013. The MPSC agrees with comments submitted by several parties, including NARUC and Centurylink, explaining that Section 27 6 gives the FCC limited authority regarding compensation to payphone owners, but does not give the FCC rate regulation over intrastate ICS. Additionally, as indicated in comments submitted by Securus Technologies, Inc., Section 152 of the Communications Act of 1934, 47 U.S.C. Section 152, does not give the FCC jurisdiction with respect to intrastate communication service.4 Therefore, the exclusive jurisdiction of intrastate rates falls to state regulators. level. The MPSC urges the FCC to leave regulation of intrastate rates at the state Dated the 9th day of January, 2014. Respectfully submitted, ~~~=== J6sffn Kraske Special Assistant Attorney General Montana Public Service Commission 1 701 Prospect A venue PO Box 202601 Helena MT 59620-2601 4 Rates for Interstate Inmate Calling Services, WC Docket No. 12-375, Comments of Securus Technologies, Inc., p.2, filed December 20,2013. 2

Respectfully, Jerry Niles, Sheriff Garfield County Sheriffs Office Enid, Oklahoma Shakespeare's Henry V, 1598 This story shall the good man teach his son; And Crispin Crispian shall ne'er go by, From this day to the ending of the world, But we in it shall be remember'd; We few, we happy few, we band of brothers; For he t<Kiay that sheds his blood with me Shall be my brother; be he ne'er so vile, This day shall gentle his condition: And gentlemen in England now a-bed Shall think themselves accursed they were not here ,And hold their manhoods cheap whiles any speaks That fought with us upon Saint Crispin's day. ~ , t . 1

filings.text_data: JOHN McMAHON, SHERIFF-CORONER November 6, 2014 John McMahon, Sheriff-Coroner 655 East Third Street S(!.Il Bernardino, CA 92415 Marlene H. Dortch, Secretary Federal Communications Commission 445 12th Street, SW Washington, DC 20554 Re: WC Docket No. 12-375 Dear Secretary Dortch, Received & Inspected Nn\/ ? ~ Z014 FCC Mail Room DOCKET FILE COPY OR\GlNAL . The San Bernardino County Sheriffs Department (SBCSD) welcomes the opportunity to comment on the FCC's proposed Rates for Interstate Inmate Calling (WC 12-375). San Bernardino County is geographically the largest county in the United States, covering over 20,000 square miles of land. SBCSD comprises the second largest corrections system in California, with an average daily population (ADP) of 6,200 incarcerated individuals. The Department provides our incarcerated population with the opportunity for educational, vocational, cognitive, alcohol and substance abuse, workforce development, community re-entry, and life-skills programs through SBCSD's Inmate Services Unit (ISU). ISU also provides for enhanced medical, nursing, and medical social work services beyond the state's requirements. Funding for benefit programs is solely through the Inmate Welfare Fund (IWF)-inmate programs are all funded by inmate generated revenues, and not by taxpayer dollars. Services and programs are provided through collaborative efforts with the California State University at San Bernardino, San Bernardino Superintendent of Schools, Chaffey Adult School, San Bernardino County Department of Workforce Development, along with professional staff at ISU. California Penal Code Section 4025 statutorily mandates revenues generated from ininate telephone and commissary commissions be deposited into the IWF. Revenues are to be used for the direct benefit of inmates such as recreation, enhanced medical services, and programs. FCC's (WC 12-375) proposal would dramatically reduce the Department IWF revenues by 52%. The impact would shock existing programs, services, goods and availabili.ty for our Department's incarcerated population, therefore rendering programs to become less effective and available. No. of Copies rec'd __ ...,O'---?list ABCDE SAN BERNARDINO COUNTY SHERIFF'S DEPARTMENT 655 East Third Street ? San Bernardino, California 92415-0061 Post Office Box 569 ? San Bernardino, California 92402-0569 } ... . . . Secretary Marlene H. Dortch WC Docket No. 12-375 Direct Budgetary Impacts to SBCSD The primary responsibility of corrections is to ensure facility, staff safety, inmate welfare and security. Monitoring of inmate calls by corrections staff and Department investigators have prevented a large number of assaults on staff and inmates, along with safeguarding witnesses, and uncovering escape plans. Call monitoring is both labor and time intensive-but it is a vital responsibility in operating inmate call systems (ICS). SBCSD's expenditures directed toward Safety and Security are approximately $456,000 per year. In addition, ICS Providers either possess or contract out investigative tools and analytics to assists corrections staff and Department investigators with the task of ensuring Safety and Security. The FCC's proposal identifies necessary investigative tools as commissions-in-kind, therefore eliminating ICS Providers from including them in competitive packages, and placing the additional expense on SBCSD. SBCSD estimates costs to the Department would be $271,700 annually to include the necessary features. Total annual expenditures for the Department to ensure facility, staff safety, inmate welfare and security will be $727, 700. All of SBCSD's recreation, education, enhanced medical services, and community re-entry programs, along with goods and services are paid through the IWF. To operate on a status-quo basis, IWF expendjtures are currently at $5,671,213. Implementation ofFCC's proposal would result in a 52% reduction in IWF's revenues, equating to $2,450,000 annually. Due to statutory mandates, along with higher and varied classifications of inmates in the Department' s correctional system, the level of services will likely increase to provide inmate and community integration programs for all incarcerated individuals within county jails. Included in commissions-in-kind are the State's statutorily required free calls. Toll free calls for recently booked arrestees are mandated by California Penal Code Section 851.5. The Department also extends free calls to inmates' attorneys and consulates. Traditionally, free calls were part of ICS competitive packages. The FCC proposal, however, would eliminate this option. Expenditures for free calls would be transferred to SBCSD's budget at the estimated amount of$345,600 annually. In total, direct impacts to SBCSD's correctional budget would significantly increase expenditures in the amount of $3,523,300 yearly just to operate at status-quo levels, disregarding additional unfunded statutory mandates, program/service technology upgrades, and increased service requests from the incarcerated population. Operations and Equipment Anticipated Annual Expenditures Safety and Security $456,000 Investigative and Analytic Tools $271 ,700 Cost for Free Calls $345,600 Loss of JCS Commissions $2,450,000 Annual Expenditures to SBCSD $3,523,300 J' . ?. Secretary Marlene H. Dortch WC Docket No. 12-375 The Commission has requested comments regarding the implementation timelines for Rates for Interstate Inmate Calling (WC 12-375). In California, commissions from ICS Providers generally constitute 50% or greater ofIWFs' total revenues to provide direct inmate benefit programs, as well as goods and services. In 2007, Senate Bill 81 (SB-81) was implemented by the California State Legislature. In response, the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR) decided to eliminate all monetary commissions from ICS Providers. CDCR was given a four-year implementation schedule and transition period to properly adjust for organizational budgets, 1 program assessment, and to make adjustments regarding management and staffing impacts. California possess a larger resource capacity than SBCSD, or the County of San Bernardino to recover from a 52% revenue reduction. SBCSD highly recommends the FCC provide the 58 California Sheriffs Departments a similar time period as was afforded to SB-81 to implement and transition Rates for Interstate Inmate Calling (WC 12-375). Overall, the San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department opposes the approval of WC 12-375 based upon the negative impacts anticipated with the delivery of inmate progr ing and th creased burden on an already strained county budget.

Stephanie A. Joyce 
Attorney 
202.857.6081 DIRECT 
202.857.6395 FAX 
joyce.stephanie@arentfox.com 

Arent Fox LLP / Attorneys at Law
Los Angeles, CA / New York, NY / San Francisco, CA / Washington, DC

555 West Fifth Street, 48th Floor 
Los Angeles, CA 90013-1065

1675 Broadway 
New York, NY 10019-5820

San Francisco, CA 94105-3470 
T 415.757.5500   F 415.757.5501 

1717 K Street, NW 
Washington, DC 20006-5344 
T 202.857.6000   F 202.857.6395 

June 30, 2016 

VIA ECFS 

Marlene H. Dortch 
Secretary 
Federal Communications Commission 
445 12th Street, S.W. 
Washington, D.C. 20554 

Re: Notice of Permitted Ex Parte Meeting, WC Docket No. 12-375 

Dear Ms. Dortch:   

On June 28, 2015, Securus Technologies, Inc. (Securus), represented by Chief Executive 
Officer Richard A. Smith, Vice President and General Counsel Dennis J. Reinhold, and the 
undersigned counsel, met with Claude Aiken, Wireline Legal Advisor to Commissioner Mignon 
Clyburn, to discuss whether a compromise resolution can be reached for Inmate Calling Services 
(ICS) rates and fees.  See WC Docket No. 12-375, Letter from Stephanie A. Joyce (Apr. 15, 
2016) (notice of meeting attended by representatives of Securus, Global Tel*Link, Pay Tel 
Communications, Inc., and Telmate LLC). 

Securus reiterated the request, proposed to Commissioner Clyburn by several ICS carriers in 
October 2015, that the Commission consider the adoption of a per-minute additive rate to 
compensate jails.  See WC Docket No. 12-375, Letter from Global Tel*Link, Securus, Pay Tel 
Communications, and Telmate to Marlene H. Dortch (notice of meeting with Commr. Clyburn); 
WC Docket No. 12-375, Letter from Stephanie A. Joyce to Chairman Tom Wheeler, et al. (Feb. 
17, 2015).  This additive rate would be part of a comprehensive solution on which the 
Commission can obtain comment. 

This disclosure is made in compliance with 47 C.F.R.  1.1206(a)(1). 

Please do not hesitate to contact me with any questions: 202.857.6081. 

Sincerely, 

s/Stephanie A. Joyce
Counsel to Securus Technologies, Inc.
Cc: Stephanie Weiner, Senior Legal Advisor to Chairman Wheeler (via electronic mail) 

Claude Aiken, Legal Advisor to Commissioner Clyburn (via electronic mail)

filings.text_data: December 10, 2014   Ms. Marlene H. Dortch Secretary Federal Communications Commission 445 12th Street, SW Washington, DC 20554  Re: WC Docket No. 12-375  Dear Ms. Dortch:  I am writing to request that the FCC grant a two-week extension on the deadlines for comments in response to the most recent Further Notice of Proposed Rulemaking in Docket 12-375.   While I fully support and share the FCC?s desire to move quickly, more time is needed to allow both the public and industry participants sufficient time to meaningfully respond to the Commission?s request for comment.   I have spoken with Lee Petro, counsel for petitioners, Paul Wright of Human Rights Defense Center, Bill Pope of NCIC, Marcus Trathen, counsel for PayTel, Tom Dethlefs of CenturyLink, and Darrell Baker of the Alabama Public Service Commission, all of whom consent to this request.  I therefore request that comments be due on January 20, 2015 and reply comments due February 4, 2015.  I thank you for your work and for considering this request.  Sincerely,   Peter Wagner Executive Director

filings.text_data: 10/24/14           6708 Autumnwood Dr.           Nashville, TN 37221   RE:  WC 12-375  Dear Secretary Dortch,  I very much appreciate the action taken by FCC to lower prison/jail interstate calling rates.  I hope more progess will be made in this area regarding rates and fees.  I am commenting today about the necessity of lowering prison/jail intrastate rates and fees.  As you know, most of the calls are intrastate, and are made to family support networks.  I am certain that these exorbitant rates and assoicated fees, can be lowered, thereby facilitating all important family connections and communication.  I certainly recognize that this will require planning and work, but it is imperative to proceed without delay.          Sincerely,         Diana Page

text_data: . Nashville, TN 37221 RE: WC 12-375

filings.text_data: William P Quigley Loyola University New Orleans College of Law 7214 St. Charles Avenue, New Orleans, LA 70118 504.861.5591  quigley77@gmail.com  November 20, 2014  Re: WC Docket 12-375  Commissioners:  I write in support of this proposal.  People in prison and people with family members in prison need to stay as closely connected as possible.  It is critically important our nation encourage these connections.  The proposal will help people in prison and their families be able to afford more frequent communications.  I have worked with hundreds of families and people in prison.  The high costs of phone communications are a constant challenge.  This proposal would certainly take these costs down and help everyone.  Thank you for your consideration.  William P. Quigley

DOCKET FILE COPY ORIGINAL EX P. . ~ATE OR lATE FILED 111111----------------------------------From: Sent: To: Cc: Subject: Cathy Coyne <ccoyne@calsheriffs.org> Monday, December 09, 2013 5:09 PM Tom Wheeler Martin J. Mayer; Carmen Green; Nick Warner; Aaron Maguire; Cory Salzillo; Ahern, Gregory, Sheriff ~=~~~~ia Sheriffs re FCC Order-we Docket No. 12-375 re ~eE~ffi~l[~~g MAR 2 5 2014 To: Tom Wheeler, FCC Chairman From: Sheriff Gregory J. Ahern, CSSA President Federal Communications Commission Re: FCC Order- WC Docket No. 12-375 re Interstate Inmate Calling Services Office of the Secretary The California State Sheriffs' Association (CSSA) urgently requests that the FCC Report and Order and Further Notice of Proposed Rulemaking on Rates for Interstate Inmate Calling Services (WC Docket No. 12-375), scheduled to go into effect February 11,2014, be stayed as it applies to Sheriffs and jails; The FCC Order mandates a one-size-fits-all approach to regulating inmate calling services for both prisons and jails. The Order fails to take into account the unique challenges inherent in providing calling services to the majority of the nation's jails that are small in size and have high turnover of inmate populations weekly. Inmate calling systems are built to the unique needs of each jail and provide a variety of important safety and security components. The Order disregards this reality and creates a regulatory environment that jeopardizes these services. Many jails may be forced to severely limit or eliminate inmate calling privileges. The FCC has recognized in its Order that jails incur real costs to administer inmate calling services; however, the rates set by the FCC eliminate commissions to jails on inter-state calls and do not include any allowance for cost recovery for jails. A STAY must be granted for jails until such time as the FCC and Sheriffs can determine a proper method for jails to recover these costs. Because Sheriffs Office budgets are already set for 2014, many Sheriffs will not have the financial resources necessary to continue to administer inmate calling services and perform the vital security functions required to protect the public. Thank you- Cathy Coyne, Legislative Analyst for Sheriff Gregory J. Ahern, CSSA President California State Sheriffs' Association 123 1 I Street, Suite 200 Sacramento, CA 95814 Phone 916-375-8000 Email: ccoyne@calsheriffs.org PRIVILEGED AND CONFIDENTIAL COMMUNICATION- This electronic transmission, and any documents attached hereto, may contain confidential and/or legally privileged information. The information is intended only for use by the recipient named above. If you have received this electronic message in error, please notify the sender and delete the electronic message. Any disclosure, copying, distribution, or use of the contents of information received in error is strictly prohibited. 1

filings.text_data: 12-04-2014 Marlene H. Dortch, Secretary Federal Communications Commission 445 121h Street, SW; Room TW-B204 Washington, DC 20554 RE: WC Docket Number 12-375 Dear Secretary Dortch, Received & Inspected nrc o a Z014 FCC Mail Room This correspondence is for the support of lowering prison phone rates. The FCC did cap long distance phone rates after 11 years of families trying. We are grateful for that change. However this order did not apply to in state calls which now in some cases, in some states are now more costly than the Jong distant rate?. !n-state calls mal:e up fot 85% of all ca!ls from prisons and jails. It is important for incarcerated persons to maintain contact with friends and family, as that helps the inmates' reintroduction into the community. Many studies show communication is critical for this to happen. Presently I am paying $1.00 connection fee for a one-half hour call and .13 a minute. The Nevada Department of Corrections keeps raising the call rates and I am not notified in advance of the rate change. I am on a fixed income and it is difficult for me to call my loved one often and still be able to pay my rent, buy my groceries and medications. May I also suggest that the large commissions paid to the department of corrections be reduced. Please make my comment part of the WC Docket Number 12-375. Regards, Ron A Ozment rJ A r'I ~ ~ -\-:-PO Box 791 \_ ~ d)') ~ 1 1 '->'-' 1 ' --College Place, WA. 99324 No. of Copies rec'd Q :_;st ABCDE --- -------.... --?---?--- -------??-~ --

filers.name: National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners

filings.text_data: NOTICE VIA ELECTRONIC FILINGJuly 21, 2014 Marlene H. Dortch, Secretary Federal Communications Commission 445 12th Street, SW Washington, D.C. 20554 RE:       Notice of Oral Ex Parte filed in the proceedings captioned:In the Matter of Rates for Intestate Inmate Calling Services, WC Docket No. 12-375  Secretary Dortch:             On Sunday, July 15, 2014, the South Dakota Commissioner Chris Nelson, Chair of the Telecommunications Committee, of the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners (NARUC)  met with FCC Commissioner Mignon Clyburn and Rebekah Goodheart, Legal Advisor to Commissioner Clyburn,  at the NARUC Summer Meetings in Dallas, Texas.  During the course of the meeting there was a discussion of the FCC?s open docket on Inmate Calling Services.  Chair Nelson generally reiterated NARUC?s on-the-record positions1 [footnote 1] filed in the FCC?s docketed proceedings that:  [1] Commend the FCC for acting expeditiously to address interstate inmate calling issues,    [2] Express our appreciation for [a] the original NPRM?s acknowledgement that intrastate ISC rates are ?set by the States,?  [3] Generally oppose arguments that would expand the FCC?s jurisdiction to intrastate toll rates or unnecessarily supplant existing State Public Service Commission decisions  over this service. Specifically, while we agree with NASUCA and others that the FCC?s authority with respect to  interstate interexchange calling is clear, the scope of the FCC?s authority to address intrastate, long-distance calls  and/or operator services is not.                                                          1  See. December 21, 2013 Comments of the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners, filed in WC Docket 12-375, available online at: http://apps.fcc.gov/ecfs/document/view?id=7520964307.   April 22, 2013 Reply Comments of the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners, filed in WC Docket 12-375, available online at: http://apps.fcc.gov/ecfs/document/view?id=7022289729.  December 28, 2012  Ex Parte Letter to the Honorable Juius Genachowski, Chairman, Federal Communications Commission, from James Bradford Ramsay, NARUC General Counsel in the Matter of the ?Wright Petition? concerning Inmate calling rates filed in CC Docket No. 96-128, http://apps.fcc.gov/ecfs/comment/view?id=6017155457.2The undersigned was not present for this meeting. However, I have attempted to cover all the key advocacy points raised during the meeting.  I am copying Ms. Goodheart with this notice.  If she indicates I have inadvertently left out some advocacy, I will immediately refile a corrected notice that includes the omitted discussions.   If you have questions about this or any other NARUC advocacy, please do not hesitate to contact me at 202.898.2207 (w), 202.257.0568(c) or at jramsay@naruc.org.             NARUC respectfully requests any waivers needed to file this ex parte out-of-time.                  Respectfully Submitted,  JAMES BRADFORD RAMSAY,GENERAL COUNSELNATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF REGULATORY UTILITY COMMISSIONERS1101 VERMONT AVENUE, SUITE 200WASHINGTON, DC 20005cc:  Rebekah Goodheart, Wireline Legal Advisor to Commissioner Clyburn,

filings.text_data: OOCKET FILE COPY ORIGINAL -EX PARTE OR LATE FILED ------------------------------------From: Sent: To: Subject: MrWheeler, andy cornell <elbertcountydetention@yahoo.com> Tuesday, December 10, 2013 9:31AM Tom Wheeler Interstate Inmate Calling ACCEPTED IF\ LED MAR 2 5 Z01 4 Federal Communications Commission Office of the Secretary We are writing in reference to WC Docket No 12-375, regarding the ICS order referencing proposed rulemaking for rates for interstate inmate calling. It is in best regards that we request that the above refernced order, which is scheduled to go into effect February 11 , 2014, be STAYED as it applies to Sheriffs and jails. Your attention to said matter is greatly appreciated. In best regards we remain, Sheriff Melvin Andrews Sheriff of Elbert County Ga Major Andy Cornell Elbert County Jail Administrator 1 -? . . ... ----- -~ .. -- --- -

filings.text_data: From: Sent: To: Cc: Chairman Wheeler, EX PARTE OR LATE FILED Jordan, Julie <Julie.Jordan@house.ga.gov> Tuesday, December 10, 2013 2:03 PM Tom Wheeler ggulledge@paulding.gov DOCKET FILE COPY ORIGINAL ACCEPTED/FILED MAR 2 5 2014 Federal Communications Commission Office of the Secretary On behalf of Sheriff Gary Gulledge of the Paulding County Sheriffs Department, I would like to request that the implementation of the ICS Order, (WC Docket No. 12-375), be postponed because the Sheriffs Office budgets for 2014 have already been set. Many sheriffs will not have the financial resources necessary to continue to administer inmate calling services and perform the vita l security functions required to protect the public. A STAY must be granted for jails until such time as the FCC and Sheriffs can determine a proper method for jails to recover these costs. I appreciate your consideration in this matter. Sincerely, Howard Maxwell State Representative District 17 1 - ? ?~-??,__,.. w-- ?-... ..... ,. __ ... ,. ....... ~- . .. _ .. ...

filings.text_data: January 13, 2014  Marlene H. Dortch, Secretary Federal Communications Commission 445 12th Street SW Washington, DC 20554  Re: Reply Comment on WC 12-375  Dear Ms. Dortch:  In the Federal Communications Commission?s August 9 2013 Report and Order and Further Notice of Proposed Rulemaking,1 the commissioners ask for confirmation that ICS providers receive a portion of the payment fee charged by third-party payment services such as Western Union.2 The issue of hidden profit in various ?fees? charged by the industry and allied businesses was a major finding of our May 2013 report ?Please Deposit All of Your Money: Kickbacks, Rates, and Hidden Fees in the Jail Phone Industry.?3  Noting that Global Tel*Link4 continues to deny receiving kickbacks from Western Union and other payment processors, we wish to draw your attention to three pieces of evidence that such payments are being made that were not available at the time of our original report:                                                 1 In re Rates for Interstate Inmate Calling Services, WC Docket No. 12-375 (Adopted August 9, 2013), available at http://apps.fcc.gov/ecfs/document/view?id=7520945713.  2 Report and Order and Further Notice of Proposed Rulemaking, In re Rates for Interstate Inmate Calling Services, WC Docket No. 12-375 at ? 168 (Adopted August 9, 2013). (?In the Order, we require charges for any services that are ancillary to the costs of providing ICS to be cost-based, and require ICS providers to submit cost data for these ancillary service charges as part of the mandatory data request. Here we seek comment on how the Commission can ensure, going forward, that ancillary charges are just, reasonable, and cost-based. For example, the record reflects that ICS providers typically use third parties to process debit and prepaid transactions, and there are concerns that the charges passed on to inmates or their called parties are not entirely cost-based. Is this accurate??) 3 Drew Kukorowski, Peter Wagner, and Leah Sakala, Please Deposit All of Your Money: Kickbacks, Rates, and Hidden Fees in the Jail Phone Industry (May 8, 2013), available at http://www.prisonpolicy.org/phones/pleasedeposit.html 4 ??ICS providers cannot control the fees established by third-parties for payment processing functions, such as Western Union or MoneyGram fees or the payment processing fees charged by credit card companies.? (Global Tel*Link Corporation, Comment, In re Rates for Interstate Inmate Calling Services, WC Docket No. 12-375 (received December 20, 2013), available at http://apps.fcc.gov/ecfs/document/view?id=7520964265.)   2 1. The Alabama Public Service Commission reviewed the evidence in that state and concluded that:   ?Money Transfer services (Western Union and MoneyGram) ? Staff recognizes that these fees are set by these financial services but is also aware that agents hosting such services are paid a portion of the fee. Additionally merchants may negotiate the fee charged their customers.?5  2. NCIC has clearly demonstrated that it is possible for providers to control the fees charged by Western Union. After the publication of our report, NCIC reached out to us to assert that the company was not receiving a revenue share from Western Union. When we asked for an explanation for why Western Union was charging NCIC Customers a rate higher than that charged to customers of other companies, NCIC renegotiated its contract with Western Union and had the rate lowered to $5.6   3. Customer Service of America (CSA), affiliated with AmTel, admits that it receives income from Western Union fees and then defends that income as necessary. CSA submitted a comment to the FCC on December 20, 1013 that appears to be responding not to the FCC but to the Alabama Public Service Commission, and makes this surprising admission:   ?CSA respectfully does not agree with a prohibition of the Call Center receiving a portion of a payment from Western?. CSA representatives frequently have to make refunds for Western Union Quick Collect payments and this portion of a processing fee helps to recover the associated refund expense.?7    Notably, the Western Union fee for AmTel is $9.95, meaning that the $10.95 and $11.95 fees charged by Western Union to Global Tel*Link and Securus customers represent an even higher profit to those companies.                                                   5 Alabama Public Service Commission, Errata and Substitute Order Proposing Revised Inmate Phone Service Rules and Establishing a Comment Period, Re: General Proceeding Considering the Promulgation of Telephone Rules Governing Inmate Phone Services, Docket 15957 (October 7, 2013), available at  http://www.psc.state.al.us/Telecom/Engineering/documents/Sub_Ala_ICS_Reform_Order.pdf 6 Prison Policy Initiative, Our Report Leads Two Phone Companies to Clarify & Improve Policies (May 28, 2013), available at http://www.prisonpolicy.org/blog/2013/05/28/policies/. 7(Emphasis added.) ATN, Inc. / AmTel Comments on Changes to Rules for Inmate Calling Services Docket #: 12-375,  In re Rates for Interstate Inmate Calling Services, WC Docket No. 12-375 (received December 20, 2013), available at http://apps.fcc.gov/ecfs/document/view?id=7520964042.   3The exact extent to which a portion of the third-party fee is actually cost-based may still be up for debate, but the FCC can be confident that a portion of the fees charged by third parties such as Western Union for payments to certain providers is in fact being collected by ICS companies.  We recommend that the FCC adopt Alabama?s approach to regulating fees and kickbacks from third party payment servicers:   ?All ICS providers shall submit, for informational purposes to the Commission, the transaction fee charged their customers by Western Union and MoneyGram for ICS payments and will update this information as the fees change. Staff will compare fees submitted by all ICS providers and require justification from ICS providers for any observed anomalies.?8  Sincerely,   Peter Wagner Executive Director    Aleks Kajstura Legal Director                                                   8 Alabama Public Service Commission, Errata and Substitute Order Proposing Revised Inmate Phone Service Rules and Establishing a Comment Period, Re: General Proceeding Considering the Promulgation of Telephone Rules Governing Inmate Phone Services, Docket 15957 (October 7, 2013) at 17, available at  http://www.psc.state.al.us/Telecom/Engineering/documents/Sub_Ala_ICS_Reform_Order.pdf

filers.name: Helping Educate to Advance the Rights of the Deaf

filings.text_data: March 25, 2013  Marlene H. Dortch, Commission Secretary Federal Communications Commission  Office of the Secretary  445 12th Street, SW  Room TW-B204  Washington, DC 20554  Re: In the Matter of Rates for Interstate Inmate Calling Services, WC Docket No. 12-375, Paragraph 42, ?Disabilities Access?  Dear Commissioners:  Helping Educate to Advance the Rights of the Deaf (?HEARD?)1 hereby submits comments from nineteen deaf prisoners representing eighteen different prisons across the nation, responding to the Commission?s request for information about rates for and access to interstate Inmate Calling Service (?ICS?) for deaf and disabled prisoners.2   HEARD is honored to deliver these comments, especially since some of these prisoners risked so much to submit them.  We trust that these letters will guide the Commission as it ensures that all prisoners have accessible and affordable contact with family, friends, advocates, and attorneys.  Respectfully Submitted,  /s/  Talila A. Lewis, Founder & President         	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?	 ?1  HEARD is an all-volunteer nonprofit organization that advocates on behalf of deaf and deaf-blind prisoners across the nation. HEARD created and maintains the only national database of deaf and deaf-blind prisoners.  See HEARD?s Public Comment in WC Docket No. 12-375 for more information.  WC Docket No. 12-375, HEARD Public Comments on Rates for and Access to Interstate Calling Services for Prisoners with Disabilities, submitted on March 25, 2013. 2  In the Matter of Rates for Interstate Calling Services, WC Docket No. 12-375, Notice of Proposed Rulemaking. Paragraph 42, ?Disabilities Access.?
